title-group.article-title: Optimizing Opioid Prescription Quantity After Cesarean Delivery: A Randomized Controlled Trial

contrib.collab: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Maternal-Fetal Medicine Units (MFMU) Network, Bethesda, MD, United States*

contrib-group.aff: Departments of Obstetrics and Gynecology of the University of Utah Health Sciences Center, Salt Lake City, UT (M.C.S., A.S.); The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH (K.R., A.B.); University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA (S.S.); University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA (H.N.S.); University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL (B.M.C.); Brown University, Providence, RI (D.J.R.); Columbia University, New York, NY (U.M.R.); University of Texas Medical Branch, Galveston, TX (G.R.S); MetroHealth Medical Center, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH (J.L.B); University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Children’s Memorial Hermann Hospital, Houston, TX (S.P.C); University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC (J.M.T.); Northwestern University, Chicago, IL (W.A.G); University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX (G.A.M); the Department of Anesthesiology, Columbia University, New York, New York (R.L.C.); the George Washington University Biostatistics Center (R.G.C., C.M); the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (M.L.).

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Marcela Smid, MD, MA, MS, 30 North Mario Capecchi Drive Salt Lake City, UT 84112 USA, Fax: (801) 585-2594 Marcela.Smid@hsc.utah.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To test whether an individualized opioid prescription protocol with a shared decision-making component (IOPP) can be used without compromising post-cesarean pain management.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: In this multicenter randomized controlled non-inferiority trial, we compared IOPP to fixed number of opioid tablets at hospital discharge. We recruited at 31 centers participating in the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Maternal-Fetal Medicine Units Network. Study participants had an uncomplicated cesarean birth. Follow-up occurred through 12 weeks post-discharge. Individuals with complicated cesarean birth or history of opioid use in the pregnancy were excluded. Participants were randomized 1:1 to IOPP or fixed amount (20 tablets of 5 mg oxycodone). In the IOPP group, we calculated recommended tablet quantity based on opioid use in the 24 hours prior to discharge. After an educational module and shared decision-making, participants selected a quantity of discharge tablets (up to 20). The primary outcome was moderate to severe pain (≥4) on the Brief Pain Inventory (0–10) at one week after discharge. A total sample size of 5,500 participants was planned to assess if IOPP was not inferior to the fixed quantity of 20 tablet.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: From September 2020 through March 2022, 18,990 individuals were screened and 5520 were enrolled (n=2748 IOPP, n=2773 fixed). IOPP was not inferior to fixed quantity for the primary outcome (59.5% vs. 60.1%, Risk Difference 0.67%; 95% CI −2.03%, 3.37%, non-inferiority margin −5.0), and resulted in significantly fewer tablets received (median 14, interquartile range [IQR] 4–20 compared to 20, p = <0.001) through 90 days postpartum.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Compared with fixed quantity, IOPP was non-inferior for outpatient post-cesarean analgesia at 1-week post-discharge and resulted in fewer prescribed opioid tablets at discharge.

abstract.title: PRÉCIS
abstract.p: Individualized opioid prescription protocol with a shared decision-making component can tailor the number of post-cesarean opioid tablets without compromising post-discharge pain management.
